data.title: Private Papers of Captain P G B Martin-Smith
data.meta_description: 6 boxes of original documents, correspondence, research notes and draft copies compiled by him during the writing of his memoir, 'Friuli '44' (246pp, written in 1980s) of his service as an officer of the Worcestershire Regiment with No.1 Special Force, SOE, in northern Italy (July 1944 – May 1945), covering his attempts to infiltrate agents into Austria and his role as British Liaison Officer with
data.text:
This media is not currently available online. Contact the Image and Film Licensing team about access

Description

Object description

6 boxes of original documents, correspondence, research notes and draft copies compiled by him during the writing of his memoir, 'Friuli '44' (246pp, written in 1980s) of his service as an officer of the Worcestershire Regiment with No.1 Special Force, SOE, in northern Italy (July 1944 – May 1945), covering his attempts to infiltrate agents into Austria and his role as British Liaison Officer with Italian partisan forces at Friuli, Italy; including discussion of the internal politics of the partisan groups, their clashes with German troops, and attempts to win over the Cossack forces in the area, and descriptions of the disagreements with Yugoslavian partisans during his attachment to the Allied Military Government in Austria (1945 – 1946) concerning spheres of influence. Also included with the collection are 9 photographs showing Italian partisans and Allied troops, original operational papers from the Friuli mission, and the published Italian version of the memoir, 'Friuli '44'.

Content description

6 boxes of original documents, correspondence, research notes and draft copies compiled by him during the writing of his memoir, 'Friuli '44' (246pp, written in 1980s) of his service as an officer of the Worcestershire Regiment with No.1 Special Force, SOE, in northern Italy (July 1944 – May 1945), covering his attempts to infiltrate agents into Austria and his role as British Liaison Officer with Italian partisan forces at Friuli, Italy; including discussion of the internal politics of the partisan groups, their clashes with German troops, and attempts to win over the Cossack forces in the area, and descriptions of the disagreements with Yugoslavian partisans during his attachment to the Allied Military Government in Austria (1945 – 1946) concerning spheres of influence. Also included with the collection are 9 photographs showing Italian partisans and Allied troops, original operational papers from the Friuli mission, and the published Italian version of the memoir, 'Friuli '44'.

Our collections information

We have over a million object records online, and we are adding to this all the time. Our records are never finished. Sometimes we discover new information that changes what we know about an object, such as who made it or used it. Sometimes we change how an object is interpreted. We sometimes make mistakes in our spelling, transcription or categorisation, or miss information out of our records.

Read more about our collections and the information we hold. Developing our collections information

If you have concerns about the language in this record, or you have information to improve it, please share your feedback.

Our collections information

Please use this form to give us feedback on an object. The form will be sent to our Collections Management Team who will use it to improve our object records. We receive a lot of comments and can't respond to each one, but we do read them all and will respond where we can.

Second World War

Christmas in Captivity

Millions of prisoners were taken captive during the Second World War and their experiences varied according to many factors – from where they had been captured to their nationality, race and whether they were a civilian or serving in the military. Explore these items from IWM’s collection to find out more about how POWs celebrated Christmas.

First World War

Military Uniform Badges and Portrait Photographs

Detachable badges in metal or cloth are a key element of military uniforms. They can be worn on a cap, collar, shoulder, arm, or cuff. They can be stitched, or attached with brass pins or ‘sliders’.
